hackathon-description-text: student hackathons are deisgned to provide NYC high school students from under-resourced communities the opportunity to develop their coding skills and work alongside professionals from NYC's tech community. Presented by the
hackathon-eligibility: This challenge is open to all New York City high school students who have
hackathon-requirements: Participants must conceive of an idea that addresses the Code4Tomorrow theme of identifying ways to make a positive change in NYC communities. Two digital products must be submitted:

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: $100 dollars to each student in the winning group.
$40 to each student in the winning group
$25 to each student in the winning group.

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion:
- Does the idea address a real problem in a NYC community? 
- What data is provided to illustrate the problem? 
- Does the prototype present a meaningful solution to the problem identified?
- Would the solution appeal to the target customer?

How complete is the prototype?
o	Is it functional?
o	Does it accomplish its stated goal?
How intuitive is the user interface?
o	Is it easy to understand?
o	Is it easy to use?

Would the website appeal to the target customer?
o	Is the content appropriate for the demographic?
o	Is the design appropriate for the demographic?

How is the overall aesthetic appeal of the website?
Do presenters effectively articulate the problem, solution, features, and corresponding benefits of the digital prototype,and why their promotional website appeals to their target market?

hackathon-description-header: With the help of industry mentors, NYC high school students will build digital products that aim to make a positive change in their academic and school communities.
